Finance & economics https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/ Finance & economics - Made with love by RSSHub(https://github.com/DIYgod/RSSHub) RS集线器i@diygod.me (DIYgod) zh-cn 2023 年 6 月 24 日星期六 22:05:20 GMT 120 Why investors can’t agree on the financial outlook

短尾矮袋鼠是一种澳大利亚有袋动物，体型与家猫相当，拥有饱满的脸颊和弯曲的嘴巴，通常会给高兴的游客留下这种动物正在微笑的印象。它被称为地球上最快乐的动物。然而如今，它面临着来自另一个物种的竞争：美国股票投资者。标准普尔500指数今年已上涨 14%。如果再上涨 10%，该指数将回到去年 1 月创下的历史新高。对人工智能的兴奋点燃了被视为潜在受益者的公司的热情。

尽管股价上涨代表着令人印象深刻的转变，但这并不是最令人惊讶的市场转变。该奖项颁给了波动性的崩溃。在过去 12 个月里， VIX指数（一个衡量股价预期波动性的指数，使用防止极端波动的保险成本）下降了一半以上，从 30 左右跌至 13。上一次如此低迷是在2020 年初，即 covid-19 爆发之前，当时对经济停滞的担忧比对通胀的担忧更为普遍。考虑到波动率有时被称为“恐惧指标”，其低水平表明股市呈现出短尾矮袋鼠般的平静状态。

考虑到投资者可能担心的事情太多，这种前景更加令人惊讶。例如，美联储的下一步行动存在相当大的不确定性，这将是投资者希望获得更多保护的充分理由。当标普500 指数在 2021 年触及较早高峰时（波动性较高的时期），联邦基金利率为零（目前为 5%），十年期国债收益率为 1.5%（目前为 3.7%）。此外，高利率可能会引发其他问题。直到硅谷银行和 Signature 银行破产前几天，美国银行业最近发生的骚乱才引起投资者的关注。另一家贷款机构“第一共和”于五月初破产。今天的乐观情绪让人很难记住那些麻烦是最近才发生的。

然而，还有另一种物种看起来不太平静。如果股票投资者是金融王国的短尾矮袋鼠，那么债券投资者就是豪猪：警惕且天生具有防御性。波动率的下降与国债市场的同类下降形成鲜明对比。尽管追踪债券市场波动保险价格的移动指数已从 3 月份的 13 年高点有所下降，但仍是新冠疫情爆发前的两倍。债券投资者仍不相信好时光已经回来。

短尾矮袋鼠和豪猪之间的情绪差异与大流行的早期阶段有很大不同，当时股票波动极大，而政府债券的波动要小得多。当时，投资者全神贯注于新冠病毒的经济影响、疫苗的开发和部署以及经济重新开放的步伐。随后通货膨胀加剧，美联储的行动成为人们关注的焦点。

观察差异并判断债券或股票市场一定是错误的，这可能很诱人。但这不太正确。如果人工智能成为主要科技公司利润的变革力量，而不是整体经济增长的变革力量，那么这对股票投资者来说将是巨大的福音，但对政府债券来说意义不大。

问题在于，这样的结果还远未确定——投资者开始根据不太可能很快实现的盈利来定价股票。基于未来 12 个月的预期收益，标准普尔500指数的市盈率已从去年底的 16 以下攀升至目前的 19。这仍然低于大流行期间设定的高点，当时盈利预期因封锁和限制而受到抑制，但高于过去二十年的任何其他时间点。

动物精神的分歧确实表明，无论是否错误，股市投资者已经抛开了几个月前他们全神贯注的担忧。他们放弃了多方面的担忧，转而对人工智能持乐观态度。缺乏波动性所暗示的乐观前景，最终不仅是对新技术将成为美国上市公司革命性的赚钱工具的判断，也是对美联储决策不会再次动摇金融体系以及经济将承受金融危机冲击的判断。利率上升。就目前情况来看，这看起来是一个大胆的赌注。 ■

; Thu, 22 Jun 2023 10:31:46 GMT /内容/svqf57k2pqpgget7f8dms5568qqbpssv https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/06/22/why-investors-cant-agree-on-the-financial-outlook Rebuilding Ukraine will require money, but also tough reforms

克莱恩经历了一个严酷的冬天。俄罗斯向民用和能源基础设施发射导弹，试图恐吓民众并切断经济增长的萌芽。它取得了一些成功。一项调查乌克兰企业的信心指数在一月份触及低点。但随着该国士兵开始反攻，经济也随之倒退。 4 月和 5 月的情绪指标表明经济扩张。随着企业寻找工人，职位空缺继续上升。预测也越来越乐观。基辅投资公司 Dragon Capital 预计今年GDP增长 4.5%。

尽管如此，还有很长的路要走：乌克兰的经济在战争开始时萎缩了三分之一以上。卡霍夫卡大坝溃决对农业造成了严重打击；许多钢铁设施被摧毁或位于俄罗斯占领区；外国投资者的谨慎态度是可以理解的；许多工人正在战斗或逃离该国。因此，政策制定者、金融家和企业界人士于 6 月 21 日至 22 日齐聚伦敦，召开年度会议。他们的任务是研究如何支持乌克兰的复苏。

当务之急是立即重建国家，以满足人民的基本需求，特别是明年冬天。乌克兰今年要求拨款 140 亿美元，其中很大一部分将用于向家庭重建家园和企业修复业务提供赠款。到目前为止，仅筹集到了其中一部分资金。

阅读更多有关重建乌克兰的文章包：

  • 建设乌克兰2.0
  • 战争正在重塑乌克兰国家——变得更好
  • 北约正在纠结是否让乌克兰加入

乌克兰还需要现金来实现长期复苏。今年 3 月，欧盟、联合国、世界银行和乌克兰政府合计预计未来 10 年的成本为 4110 亿美元，这一数字在卡霍夫卡大坝被毁之前就达到了。世界银行下属的国际金融公司认为，由于很难吸引私人资金，三分之二的资金需要来自公共来源。这相当于每年西方同期GDP的 0.1%。在伦敦，欧盟委员会主席乌苏拉·冯德莱恩提议欧盟应在2027年之前以赠款和贷款的形式提供45%的资金。

接下来是改革。经验丰富的捐助国专家对乌克兰迄今为止在战争条件下取得的成就印象深刻。该国已完成国际货币基金组织的一项计划，并继续进行改革，以提高财产交易和公共采购的透明度，这意味着国际捐助者可以使用该国备受赞誉的 Prozorro 在线平台，该平台使信息公开并可通过数字方式访问。该国还完成了与欧盟开启正式入盟谈判所需的七项司法和反腐败改革中的两项。

乌克兰和欧盟之间的电力市场一体化显示了推进的价值。作为向西方转移的一部分，这一进程早就计划好了，但在俄罗斯入侵后加速了。乌克兰方面进行了技术调整和痛苦的市场改革，以创建一个竞争性的、开放的批发市场。乌克兰最大的能源公司之一dtek的老板马克西姆·蒂姆琴科(Maxim Timchenko) 表示：“欧盟政治家如此迅速地实现一体化是非常勇敢的。”勇敢得到了回报。乌克兰和欧盟能够进行电力贸易，投资者可以开始挖掘乌克兰绿色能源的巨大潜力。

现在的问题是这些私人资金能否真正到位。在战争条件下，投资者通常需要公共机构的某种担保才能采取行动。伦敦正在考虑的一个想法是，捐助者不仅要提供战争保险或担保，还要帮助支撑再保险市场。

如果可以安排这样的保证，最后一步将是利用机会，考虑到流入乌克兰的援助数量和该国的经济潜力，这些机会应该是充足的。一些观察人士甚至认为，私人投资可能超过乌克兰长期重建所需的 4110 亿美元。但这只是在一切按计划进行的情况下。乌克兰改革者需要从其同胞在战场上的勇敢中汲取灵感，外国投资者也一样。 ■

; Thu, 22 Jun 2023 10:30:14 GMT /内容/5ojq03bgej9ef7und2booac2puvo81ff https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/06/22/rebuilding-ukraine-will-require-money-but-also-tough-reforms India’s journey from agricultural basket case to breadbasket

印度农业名声不佳，这并不公平。该国大约一半的劳动力在土地上劳作。他们的劳动在酷热中进行，往往是手工完成，或者使用无遮蔽的简陋车辆完成。季节性融资通常通过非正式渠道进行，贷款年利率接近30%。债务瘫痪的情况并不少见。生产效率低；玉米、水稻、小麦和其他农作物的产量只是美国、中国和欧洲的一小部分。在该国的农业中心地带旁遮普邦，路边的标志放弃了典型的汽车、电影和电话广告，转而兜售外语培训、海外教育和加急签证。当地农民想要的不是新玩意，而是一条出路。

然而，从某种意义上说，印度农业并没有停滞不前，而是正在蓬勃发展。工作条件可能很严峻，但创纪录的收成接踵而至，饥荒已成为过去。截至 3 月份的财年，农产品出口较前 12 个月增长 9%，达到 260 亿美元，占印度对外贸易的 7%。去年俄罗斯入侵乌克兰后发生的全球粮食恐慌期间，印度成为大米和小麦（它是世界第二大谷物生产国）以及其他谷物的主要出口国。其中一个例子是，中国最近同意向阿富汗塔利班运送 2000 万吨小麦，去年的数量增加到 4000 万吨。

如果不是政府实施周期性的出口限制和附加税，印度对全球农业来说将更加重要。这些限制并不是唯一的官方障碍。化肥和农药的补贴耗尽了土壤肥力。出于对化学残留的担忧，一些国家有时会禁止从印度进口。最低价格支持导致水资源匮乏、含水层枯竭的地区重点种植水稻等需水作物。对销售的限制意味着农场常常被划分为更小、效率更低的小块土地。平均拥有土地从 20 世纪 70 年代末的 5 英亩减少到今天的 2.5 英亩。为了最大限度地提高如此小块土地的产量，印度北部的小麦农民焚烧收获后的残茬，以缩短收获和播种之间的时间，从而在大部分土地上产生厚厚的有毒云层。

然而，印度农业在政策、技术和金融方面已经开始发生微妙的演变，这有助于绕过许多官方限制。这一点在经济数据中体现得淋漓尽致。十多年前，农业和制造业产生了类似的总增加值，这一指标是从收入中减去购买成本以获取对经济活动的贡献。最新数据显示，农业的贡献增加了四分之一。

印度最重要的私人金融机构hdfc银行已将农业贷款从 2015 年的 12 亿美元增加到去年的 75 亿美元，收取的利率约为非正规市场利率的三分之一到一半。 HDFC走到哪里，其他私营银行就会跟到哪里。贷款热潮正在帮助农民大幅降低成本，也意味着他们不太可能遭遇偶尔暴力的高利贷者。

供应链也日益创新。 2020 年，在新冠肺炎 (covid-19) 封锁期间，阿努什卡·内约尔 (Anushka Neyol) 从德里搬到了位于巴基斯坦边境附近的家庭农场，她曾在那里从事婴儿水疗中心等初创公司的工作。她开始尝试小麦的种类，以及通过互联网进行分销，绕过僵化的政府拍卖机构“曼迪系统”，直接销售给大城市的面包店和餐馆。客户包括孟买的一家咖啡连锁店 Subko，该公司提供独特来源的咖啡、巧克力和小麦。

另一种方法可以在距离孟买内陆约 170 公里的城市纳西克看到。 2004 年，当地居民 Vilas Shinde 开始从一个小农场出口葡萄。六年后，他成立了一家合作社，萨亚德里农场。合作社在印度有着悠久而明显的好坏参半的记录。他们已经以多种不同的形式进行了尝试，但通常会在几年内因分歧而消失。萨亚德里的成功至少表明另一种结果是可能的。该合作社目前拥有约 21,000 个农场，主要生产不纳入官方定价和分销系统的水果和蔬菜。它的规模足以证明国际市场所需的检查和运输是合理的。客户包括印度斯坦联合利华（Hindustan Unilever）的西红柿、沃尔玛（Walmart）的冷冻水果和欧洲葡萄杂货商网络，这反映了全国种植此类作物的趋势，这些作物更适合印度炎热的天气和廉价的劳动力。萨亚德里 (Sahyadri) 周围是印度葡萄酒产业的萌芽，其中包括一家名为苏拉葡萄园 (Sula Vineyards) 的酒庄。

与此同时，技术和市场力量正在渗透到更广泛的生产过程中。咨询公司麦肯锡估计，印度至少有 1000 家“农业科技”公司，已筹集了约 16 亿美元资金。通过廉价的智能手机应用程序，卫星数据现在可以提供有关土壤处理、播种和收获日期以及何时以及如何使用化肥和农药的指导。这些变化吸引了大量关注并激发了投资者的兴趣，模糊了实际限制。拜访一位农民，他的廉价手机屏幕破裂、内存有限、连接不稳定，很明显，转型必须温和地展开。到那时，一些可能的采用者将会看到旁遮普道路旁边的广告牌上的文字并前往其他地方。但变化——停滞的、隐藏的、局部的——正在扎根。 ■

; Thu, 22 Jun 2023 09:49:22 GMT /内容/anm127hec9fiqshn6l2olck18geg0mlo https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/06/22/indias-journey-from-agriculture-basket-case-to-breadbasket Can the West build up its armed forces on the cheap?

世界各地的国防开支正在蓬勃发展。俄罗斯入侵乌克兰和中国对台湾的图谋让北约31个成员国中的24个未能实现该俱乐部国防预算占国内生产总值2%的目标，其中24个成员国因俄罗斯入侵乌克兰和中国对台湾的图谋而沾沾自喜，他们承诺将实现这一目标。去年中国自己的军费开支实际增长了4.2%。在全球范围内，新的国防承诺和预测支出总计超过 2000 亿美元，在合理的假设下，这一数字可能高达 7000 亿美元。

这代表了长达数十年衰退的突然逆转。第二次世界大战期间，盟军将国内生产总值的一半用于战争。 20 世纪 60 年代，在冷战最激烈的时期，政府通常将GDP的 6% 用于国防。但苏联解体后，世界从国防开支缩减中收获了“和平红利”。去年全球国防支出为 2.2 万亿美元，略高于GDP的 2%，接近历史最低水平。

随着支出开始增加，出现了一个难题。为什么即将到来的账单没有更大？即使政客们兑现了最近的承诺，相对于GDP而言，世界的国防支出也将比 1990 年减少。

部分答案在于这样一个事实：国防开支避免了困扰许多政府的一个问题：成本病。这个问题首先由经济学家 William Baumol 在 20 世纪 60 年代提出。这种弊病也适用于医疗保健和教育等劳动密集型行业，这些行业的生产率增长缓慢，因为自动化很难。随着创新提高制造业等领域的产出和工资，有必要向护士和教师支付更高的工资，以阻止他们辞职前往最近的工厂。因此，随着时间的推移，遭受成本病困扰的行业必须增加实际支出，才能维持原状。鲍莫尔有先见之明地担心医疗保健支出会占据国内生产总值的更大份额。

武装部队从相反的现象中受益。将此称为“洛克希德定律”，以美国国防承包商巨头的名字命名。用鲍莫尔的话说，在“人与人之间的接触至关重要”的地方，疾病的叮咬成本很高。然而在美国，只有三分之一的国防开支用于支付工资。事实上，每一个未能达到北约2% 目标的国家，其武装部队人员支出占GDP的比例都更接近美国，而不是山姆大叔的其他武装部队支出。这表明，武装北约将更多地是购买额外的高级装备，而不是大肆招聘。

尽管俄罗斯和乌克兰部署了庞大的征兵部队，但正在重新武装的西方国家仍然大多坚持质量胜于数量的理念。按照逻辑，拥有一支配备最先进火炮、坦克、飞机和装备的小型军队比拥有生锈装备的大型军队更好。就其寻求与对手进行人力竞争而言，西方试图通过北约等大联盟来实现这一目标（即通过在各国之间分摊劳动力成本，而不是将更大比例的工人变成士兵）。

国防自动化还有很大的空间：例如，机器学习已经取代了人类卫星图像分析师。像洛克希德这样生产军用装备的公司不存在生产力问题——恰恰相反。美国统计学家编制了装备的价格指数，涵盖从导弹到舰艇的所有物品。这些指数背后的计算极其复杂。他们可以回答十岁男孩可能会问的问题。炸掉敌人阵地要花多少钱？乘坐军用飞机以每小时 1,000 英里的速度飞行需要多少钱？生成的数据显示，武装部队的能力已经变得相对便宜：自 20 世纪 70 年代以来，经过质量调整的导弹价格已下降了约 30%。以现金计算，美国在军用飞机上的支出与 20 世纪 80 年代中期大致相同。尽管美元在整个经济中的购买力在此期间有所下降，但它仍能购买大约相同数量的空中力量。

结果是，预算缩减仍然可以购买强大的军队。经济增长使这种影响更加明显。驻扎在南海的士兵们都清楚地知道，中国的军事实力比三十年前强大得多。然而，到 2021 年，它的国防支出占GDP的 1.7%，低于 1990 年的 2.5%。

枪口下

洛克希德定律并非没有限制。突然的国防开支往往会导致短缺，从而导致价格飙升。武装乌克兰后，北约现在需要补充武器库存，但国防供应线却捉襟见肘。更深远的是，卫生和教育支出让人们的生活变得更好。国防开支通常用于预防威胁和击退对手。如果仅仅因为世界变得更加危险就必须增加军事支出，那么这是一种不受欢迎的额外成本。和平红利并非神话。

归根结底，战争中重要的不是一个国家防御能力的绝对水平，而是它相对于敌人的实力。如果每个人都在提升能力，那么结果将是一场军备竞赛，每一项创新都必须相应增加支出。例如，技术变革使俄罗斯能够向平民发射装有炸药的伊朗无人机，这增加了保卫乌克兰的成本。在零和战争中，只有西方独自拥有的技术才能真正被认为有助于控制成本。大国之间的热战仍将导致国防开支飙升至令人痛苦的高水平。

尽管如此，这仍会让西方政治家放心——他们中的许多人正在努力满足人口老龄化的需求、加速脱碳并应对不断增加的利息支付——由于经济逻辑的纯粹力量，他们必须花费的一切都变得更加昂贵。可以在不无休止地增加成本的情况下增强一些军事力量。 ■

; Thu, 22 Jun 2023 09:46:02 GMT /内容/60c1bs0f9t52f1cdc5j9p2cbc41nfr2f https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/06/22/can-the-west-build-up-its-armed-forces-on-the-cheap Against expectations, oil and gas remain cheap

在俄罗斯入侵乌克兰后的几个月里，任何坏消息的暗示都会导致能源价格飙升。当火灾迫使美国一家天然气工厂关闭、罢工堵塞法国石油码头、俄罗斯要求欧洲以卢布支付燃料费用或天气看起来比平常更严峻时，市场变得疯狂。然而，自一月份以来，情况有所不同。全球石油基准布伦特原油价格一直徘徊在每桶 75 美元左右，而一年前为每桶 120 美元；在欧洲，天然气价格为每兆瓦时 ( mw h) 35 欧元（38 美元），比 8 月份的峰值低 88%。

这并不是说新闻突然变得更容易接受。石油输出国组织（欧佩克）及其盟国已宣布大幅减产。在美国，石油和天然气钻井平台的数量连续七周下降，因为生产商对所提供的微薄回报做出反应。挪威的几个天然气设施（现在对欧洲至关重要）正在长期维护中。荷兰正在关闭欧洲最大的天然气田。然而，任何价格上涨都会很快消失。是什么让事情保持稳定？

令人失望的需求可能是答案的一部分。近几个月来，对全球经济增长的预期有所下降。今年春天几家银行的倒闭引发了人们对美国经济衰退的担忧。通货膨胀正在打击欧洲消费者。在这两个地方，加息的全面影响仍有待感受到。与此同时，在中国， 疫情过后的反弹弱于预期。增长乏力反过来又抑制了对燃料的需求。

然而仔细观察就会发现，需求故事充其量只是片面的。尽管复苏令人失望，中国 4 月份的原油消耗量仍达到 1600 万桶/日，创历史新高。自严峻的零疫情时期以来，卡车运输、旅游业和旅行的反弹意味着柴油、汽油和航空燃油的使用量增加。在美国，汽油价格比一年前下降了 30%，这预示着夏季驾驶季节将迎来良好的发展。在亚洲和欧洲，高温预计将持续下去，从而对用于冷却的燃气发电产生更多需求。

更令人信服的解释可以在等式的供给侧找到。过去两年的高油价刺激了欧佩克以外国家的生产，目前欧佩克已开始生产。石油通过常规油井（巴西和圭亚那）以及页岩和焦油砂生产（美国、阿根廷和加拿大）从大西洋盆地喷涌而出。挪威也在增加抽水量。摩根大通银行估计，2023 年非欧佩克国家产量将增加 2.2mb/d。

从理论上讲，这应该通过欧佩克核心成员国（1.2兆桶/日）和俄罗斯（50万桶/日）4月份宣布的减产来平衡，其中沙特阿拉伯本月又增加了100万桶/日的减产。然而，这些国家的产量并没有像承诺的那样下降，而且其他欧佩克国家正在增加出口。得益于美国巨头雪佛龙的投资，委内瑞拉的石油价格有所上涨。伊朗的制裁达到 2018 年美国实施新制裁以来的最高水平。事实上，现在世界上五分之一的石油来自受西方禁运的国家，以折扣价出售，从而有助于抑制价格。

对于天然气而言，供应情况更为棘手：俄罗斯输往欧洲的主要管道仍然关闭。但自由港液化天然气公司（Freeport Lng）已恢复运营，该工厂负责处理美国五分之一的液化天然气出口，去年因爆炸而受损。俄罗斯继续对欧洲大陆进行其他出口。挪威的流量将于七月中旬完全恢复。最重要的是，欧洲现有库存巨大。该集团的存储设施已满 73%，而一年前为 53%，并有望在 12 月之前达到 90% 的目标。日本和韩国等富裕的亚洲国家也拥有充足的天然气。

当通货膨胀飙升且利率保持适度时，大宗商品（尤其是原油）是对抗价格上涨的有吸引力的对冲工具，随着投资者涌入而推高价格。现在，投机者预计通货膨胀会下降，吸引力已经减弱，就像利率上升会使价格上涨一样。现金和债券等更安全的资产更具吸引力。结果，投机性净头寸（投资者在石油期货市场上的多头和空头头寸之间的平衡）大幅下降。较高的利率还提高了持有原油库存的机会成本，因此现货交易商正在抛售库存。浮式储存量从1月份的8000万桶下降至4月份的6500万桶，为2020年初以来的最低水平。

今年晚些时候价格很可能上涨。官方预测机构国际能源署预计，2023年全球石油需求将达到创纪录的102.3mb/d。石油供应也将创下历史新高，但预测机构预计，2023年下半年市场将陷入赤字。 2023 年——许多银行的共同观点。随着冬季临近，亚洲和欧洲之间对液化天然气货物的竞争将加剧。冬季的运费已经在预期中上涨。

尽管如此，去年的噩梦不太可能重演。许多分析师预计布伦特原油价格将保持在每桶 80 美元附近，并且不会达到三位数。亚洲和欧洲的天然气期货市场预计到秋季将比目前的水平上涨 30%，而不是更极端的情况。过去 12 个月，大宗商品市场已经适应。现在，只需要一点点坏消息就可以推动价格飙升。 ■

; Mon, 19 Jun 2023 20:14:16 GMT /内容/37789npnjcdcf6fgo9frsmk5pbqvvivd https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/06/19/against-expectations-oil-and-gas-remain-cheap China’s economy is on course for a “double dip”

中国以坚定不移的领导地位和稳定的经济增长而自豪。这应该使它的命运很容易预测。但近几个月来，世界第二大经济体充满了意外，让经验丰富的中国观察家和精明的投资者都措手不及。

例如，今年年初，由于中国突然退出covid-19 控制，中国经济增长快于预期。然后，在四月和五月，发生了相反的情况：经济复苏速度比预期慢。零售销售、投资和房地产销售数据均低于预期。中国城市青年失业率超过20%，为2018年首次有数据记录以来的最高水平。一些人现在认为，与第一季度相比，第二季度经济可能根本不会增长。野村银行的陆挺表示，按照中国的标准，这将是一次“二次探底”。

中国也违背了第三个预测。值得庆幸的是，它未能成为世界经济中的通胀力量。今年石油需求的增加并没有阻止全球基准布伦特原油的成本较 1 月份的峰值下跌超过 10%。钢铁和铜也变得更便宜。 5 月份，中国的生产者价格（工厂出厂价格）与去年同期相比下降了 4% 以上。而且人民币已经走弱。美国劳工统计局的数据显示，5 月份美国人从中国进口的商品价格比去年同期下降了 2%。

经济放缓在很大程度上可以归因于中国的房地产市场。今年早些时候，该公司似乎正在从灾难性的违约、销量暴跌和抵押贷款抵制中恢复过来。政府让负债累累的房地产开发商更容易筹集资金，以便他们能够完成推迟的建设项目。去年中国突然实施封锁期间没有购买的家庭在 2023 年前几个月重返市场，进行他们推迟的购买。一些分析师甚至担心房地产市场是否会反弹过于强劲，从而重振过去的投机势头。

然而，这种被压抑的需求似乎已经逐渐消失。高盛银行的一项指数显示，5 月份新房价格环比下降。尽管房地产开发商热衷于完成建筑项目，但他们却不愿意开工。咨询公司龙洲经讯(Gavekal Dragonomics)计算出，房地产销售已回落至2019年同期水平的70%，这是中国最后一个相对正常的一年。新屋开工率仅为当时水平的 40% 左右（见下页图表）。

政府应该如何应对？在令人担忧的几周里，决策者们似乎根本不会采取任何行动。今年的官方增长目标——5%左右——缺乏雄心。北京似乎热衷于控制地方政府的债务，地方政府常常被敦促为了增长而挥霍。作为中央银行的中国人民银行（ PBOC ）似乎对物价下跌并不感到不安。它还可能担心降息会对银行的利润造成太大挤压，因为银行支付的存款利率可能不会像贷款利率那样下降。

但6月6日，中国人民银行要求中国最大的银行降低存款利率，为央行在6月13日降低政策利率0.1个百分点铺平了道路。银行向“优质”客户收取的利率随后随之下降，这将进一步降低抵押贷款利率。尽管削减幅度可以忽略不计，但这表明政府并未忽视这一危险。 6 月 16 日，中国国务院召开会议，暗示还将采取更多措施。

摩根士丹利银行的Robin Xing预计利率将进一步下调。他还认为，一二线城市的购房限制可能会放宽。该国的“政策性银行”可能会为基础设施提供更多贷款。地方政府可能被允许发行更多债券。中国的预算显示，预计 2023 年土地出让金将保持稳定。但迄今为止，收入却下降了约 20%。邢先生指出，如果全年缺口持续存在，地方政府将损失超过1万亿元人民币（1400亿美元）的收入。中央政府可能觉得有义务填补这一空白。

这足以满足政府的增长目标吗？邢先生是这么认为的。他认为，第二季度的放缓只不过是一个“小插曲”。邢先生估计，今年中国服务业的就业人数比没有新冠疫情的情况下少了 3000 万。餐馆等“接触密集型”服务业的反弹应该会在未来 12 个月内恢复其中 1600 万个就业岗位。当就业确实回归时，收入和支出将会复苏。另有 1000 万个就业岗位消失在电子商务和教育等行业，这些行业在 2021 年遭受了监管风暴。中国近几个月对这些公司采取了温和的态度，这可能会鼓励其中一些公司在经济复苏时恢复招聘。 。

其他经济学家则不那么乐观。中银国际的徐高认为，进一步的货币宽松不会起作用。由于经济中最大的两个借款人——房地产开发商和地方政府——都受到债务的困扰，贷款需求对利率不敏感。当局降息更多是出于无奈，而不是希望。

他可能是对的。但在真正尝试之前就认为货币宽松政策不会奏效，这很奇怪。贷款需求并不是重振经济的唯一渠道。 Zhang Bin of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences and his co-authors estimate that if the central bank's policy rate dropped by two percentage points, it would cut interest payments by 7.1trn yuan, increase the value of the stockmarket by 13.6trn yuan and lift house prices, bolstering the confidence of homeowners.

如果货币宽松政策不起作用，政府将不得不探索财政刺激措施。去年，地方政府融资平台（ LGFV ）是国家支持的准商业实体，增加了投资支出以支撑经济增长。 That has left many strapped for cash.研究公司荣鼎集团 (Rhodium Group) 最近对其中 2,892 辆汽车进行的调查显示，只有 567 辆手头有足够的现金来偿还短期债务。在甘肃省省会兰州和以风景如画的喀斯特山脉而闻名的南方城市桂林这两个城市，地方政府融资平台支付的利息已达到该市“财政能力”（定义为财政收入加上净收入）的100%以上。来自其融资工具的现金流量）。他们的债务堆积如山，情况并不美好。

If the economy needs more of a push, the central government will have to engineer it. In principle, this stimulus could include extra spending on pensions and consumer giveaways. The government has, for example, extended tax breaks on electric vehicles that have helped boost car sales.

Officials could also experiment with high-tech consumer handouts of the kind pioneered by cities in Zhejiang province during the early days of covid. They distributed millions of coupons through e-wallets, which would, for example, knock 70 yuan off a restaurant meal if the coupon holder spent at least 210 yuan in a week. According to Zhenhua Li of Ant Group Research Institute and co-authors, these coupons packed a punch. They induced more than three yuan of out-of-pocket spending for every one yuan of public money.

不幸的是，中国财政当局似乎仍然认为此类补贴是轻率或挥霍的。如果政府要支出或放贷，它希望为自己的麻烦创造一种耐用的资产。 In practice, any fiscal push is therefore likely to entail more investment in green infrastructure, intercity transport and other public assets favoured in China's five-year plan. That would be an utterly unsurprising response to China's year of surprises. ■

; Sun, 18 Jun 2023 15:15:01 GMT /内容/2rm7jg2gpdi98kudnvjf5s1cbkv7hfsa https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/06/18/chinas-economy-is-on-course-for-a-double-dip Wage-price spirals are far scarier in theory than in practice

A wage-price spiral is the stuff of inflationary nightmares. It refers to a situation when prices gallop higher—perhaps because of a sudden shock or policy missteps, or both—and wages race upward to keep pace with them, in turn feeding through to yet more price rises and yet more wage increases, and so on in a vicious circle. It can seem as if the world's economies have been living this horror: in America hourly earnings rose by about 6% last year, the biggest annual increase in four decades. In Britain wages excluding bonuses are rising at an annual clip of about 7%. On June 14th, when the Federal Reserve elected to leave interest rates unchanged after ten consecutive increases, Jerome Powell, its chairman, warned that he was watching wage trends as one test of whether the central bank might resume raising rates in July.

但噩梦中出现的危险通常与现实中值得担心的威胁几乎没有相似之处。过去两年，世界各地因通货膨胀而经历的令人不安的旅程似乎表明了关于工资价格螺旋式上升的类似结论：它们是存在通货膨胀问题的经济体所发生的情况的讽刺画。

The historical parallel often trotted out in discussing wage-price spirals is the 1970s. Price and wage inflation seemed to interact throughout that decade, much as the spiral framework suggests. Each surge in general price inflation was followed by a surge in wage inflation, which was followed by more price inflation—and on it went. But the 1970s are flawed as evidence for the existence of spirals. The repeated waves of inflation stemmed more from successive oil-price shocks (in 1973 and 1978) than from prior wage gains. To the extent that wages and prices moved in lockstep, this reflected trade unions' practice back then of pegging salaries to the cost of living, guaranteeing a ratchet effect. Spirals were a feature of contracts rather than proof of an economic concept.

Late last year a group of economists at the IMF interrogated the historical record, creating a database of wage-price spirals in advanced economies dating back to the 1960s. Applying a fairly low bar—they looked for accelerating consumer prices and rising nominal wages in at least three out of four consecutive quarters—they identified 79 such episodes. But a few quarters of high inflation is not all that scary. A few years is far more frightening. Judged by this longer standard, the IMF economists offered a more upbeat conclusion: the “great majority” (they omitted the exact percentage) of short-term spirals were not followed by a sustained acceleration in wages and prices.

在三月份的一份报告中，美联储芝加哥分行经济学家 Gadi Barlevy 和 Luojia Hu 仔细研究了工资在当前通胀中的作用。 They focused on “non-housing services”, a category that covers everything from car washes to medical check-ups and which Mr Powell regularly cites as a useful indicator because of its tight association with wages. Mr Barlevy and Ms Hu concluded that wages do help to explain this segment of inflation: nominal wage gains have outstripped productivity growth by a sizeable margin over the past year. Facing that cost squeeze, service providers would naturally want to raise prices.

However, the spiral thesis claims not merely that wages matter, but that they predict future inflationary trends. On this count, the Chicago Fed economists found the relationship unidirectional: inflation helps to forecast changes in labour costs, but changes in labour costs fail to predict inflation. Service providers, in other words, raised prices before rising wage costs hit their bottom line. Mr Barlevy and Ms Hu posit that employers may have been ahead of the curve in anticipating the effects of a tight labour market. That makes wages a lagging, not a leading, indicator for inflation.

Adam Shapiro, an economist with the San Francisco Fed, has been even more critical of the wage worries. In a note in May, he isolated unexpected changes in wages to argue that rising labour costs were only a small driver of non-housing service inflation and a negligible one in broader inflation. Like his Chicago colleagues, he concluded that wage growth was following inflation.

None of this means that wage-price spirals are a total myth, which some overeager commentators have written. As the IMF 's study noted, serious spirals can occur; it is just that they are extremely unusual. Were inflation to stay very high for a long time, people might start to view fast-rising prices as a basic fact of life and incorporate that assumption into their wage demands. It is possible that this process has begun in Britain.

但在美国，过去两年引人注目的是，尽管价格面临压力，但通胀预期仍然相对温和。 In a paper last month for the Brookings Institution, a think-tank, Ben Bernanke, a former chairman of the Fed, and Olivier Blanchard, a former chief economist of the IMF , decomposed the drivers of pandemic-era inflation. They concluded that a triumvirate of shocks (commodity-price spikes, strong demand for goods and supply shortages) accounted for most of the inflation overshoot since 2020. There was scant evidence that inflation itself had triggered higher wage demands. Wages shot up simply because demand for workers outstripped supply.

Dreaming spirals

Wages and prices can be driven up by the same force: excessive spending in the economy compounded by shortages of both products and the workers to produce them. Overheated economies are worth worrying about regardless of whether prices and wages are feeding on each other.

For their part, Messrs Bernanke and Blanchard argue that as pandemic shocks fade away, overheated labour markets are likely to contribute more to inflation. To stop that, central bankers need to make sure that the demand for workers cools off. Only if inflation persists once the labour market is back in balance will fear of a self-sustaining spiral be worth losing sleep over. ■

; Thu, 15 Jun 2023 10:15:02 GMT /content/sf4nb4e8i9511e5m0ni0koutp307gpin https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/06/15/wage-price-spirals-are-far-scarier-in-theory-than-in-practice South Korea has had enough of being called an emerging market

I n the 1960 s South Korea was a poor, backward country recovering from a devastating war. Now it is the 12th-largest economy in the world. Its 52m people earn an average of $35,000 a year, nearly as much as Italians and way more than Iberians. Its stockmarket is the 16th-biggest globally, with a capitalisation of $1.8trn, and the seventh-busiest by daily traded volumes. The IMF has deemed South Korea an advanced economy since 1997. Anyone still describing it as an emerging market might therefore appear to have been asleep for the past half-century.

And yet this is what MSCI , a company that creates market benchmarks, has been doing for three decades. South Korea was the 13th country to join its Emerging Market Index, which now counts 24 members. Some have since been relegated to a “frontier” basket (Croatia, Morocco), shunted to “standalone” markets (Argentina) or even dropped altogether (Venezuela). Less glitzy economies than South Korea's, such as Greece and Portugal, were elevated to MSCI ’s Developed Market index years ago. South Korea therefore thinks it is overdue a promotion. It may hope to achieve one on June 22st, when MSCI announces which countries stand a chance to receive the accolade next year.

The index provider has long pointed out that investing in South Korean assets is often an unnerving experience. Shareholders' rights are weak. Ownership structures are byzantine. Repeated scandals expose lapses in governance. And state interventions routinely warp markets.

To address such misgivings the government in January announced a raft of ambitious reforms. Rules governing the distribution of dividends, for years clear as mud, will be brought closer to Western standards. Procedures for takeovers and spin-offs will be revamped to better protect minority shareholders. An arduous registration process for foreign investors will be abolished by the end of the year, with large South Korean companies required to release filings in English from then on (smaller firms are slated to follow in 2026). Most important for MSCI , South Korea has pledged to open up its foreign-exchange market and to extend its working hours, which should help make the won more tradable internationally.

Such reforms aim to make South Korea's financial markets more dynamic—a worthy goal in itself. But the government reckons inclusion in MSCI ’s elite benchmark is also worth angling for, because it would bring with it a vast influx of cash from foreign investors. About $3.5trn of assets under management, spread across the globe, currently track MSCI ’s Developed Market index—nearly twice as much as the money following its emerging-market cousin, according to Goldman Sachs, an investment bank. Analysts estimate that a promotion could lure some $46bn-56bn of fresh capital into South Korean assets.

Moving on up could also help put an end to the “Korean discount”—the persistently lower valuation of South Korean firms relative to foreign ones with similar earnings and assets. Investors had to contend with poor governance and shareholders' rights, along with the nagging risk of a conflict with North Korea; they often received meagre dividends for their trouble. By signalling that the regime is becoming friendlier, the logic goes, an msci upgrade would help dispel investors' doubts.

The trouble is that South Korea has been there before. It made it on to MSCI ’s coveted watchlist in 2009, only to be crossed off in 2014 after the index provider alleged it was not sufficiently upping its game. Various administrations have since aimed for the promotion but failed to set adequate reforms in motion.

Some critics paint even the latest batch of measures as half-hearted. South Korea has ruled out some changes the MSCI would like, such as removing limits on foreign ownership in key industries and loosening restrictions on short-selling. And political whims continue to make investors queasy. Last year bond markets experienced a wild few days after a provincial governor refused to honour the region's debts. In February the country's president, Yoon Suk-yeol, ordered the markets watchdog to keep a lid on banks' profits, because they are “part of the public system”. Investors were unimpressed.

MSCI has already indicated that this might still not be South Korea's year. On June 8th it hinted that it would wait until the capital-market reforms were fully implemented and see how investors react to them before considering adding the country to its premier league.

That might be a blessing in disguise. South Korea should not rush into an upgrade, says Hwang Sun-woo of Korea University. Its economy, which depends heavily on exports, could be rocked in the event of a hasty opening of its foreign-currency markets. And the potential rewards should be put into perspective. The expected capital inflows, small relative to the size of South Korea's markets, would mostly benefit big companies. They could also be reversed. After luring money upon its promotion in 2010, Israel, the country to most recently graduate to developed-market status, suffered $2.5bn in net outflows the next year, which erased all earlier gains.

Membership of elite clubs will not in itself cure South Korea's reputational ills; after all, these have persisted despite its inclusion in top indices created by other blue-chip providers, such as Dow Jones and FTSE Russell. To do so, the reforms will have to convince a wider public. ■

; Thu, 15 Jun 2023 10:12:22 GMT /content/sbhu2u6dkkbog8dphpas1vh2nhfom6tn https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/06/15/south-korea-has-had-enough-of-being-called-an-emerging-market America is losing ground in Asian trade

T he intensifying rivalry between America and China has not been kind to open markets. Letting defence or foreign ministers dictate trade policy, it turns out, is not conducive to making goods move more smoothly across borders. Yet even as globalisation crumbles, a race to gain commercial clout in the world's most populous and fastest-growing region has kicked off. It is a race China is quietly winning.

Both America and China are keen to trumpet to Asian countries the benefits of the regional pacts they sponsor (each of which excludes their rival power). On May 27th a group of 14 countries agreed to set up an early-warning system over supply-chain problems—the first building block of the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework ( IPEF ), President Joe Biden's flagship offering. On June 2nd the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership ( RCEP ), a China-backed trade deal which includes Australia, Japan, New Zealand, all of South-East Asia (bar East Timor) and South Korea, came into force in the Philippines, the last of the pact's 15 members to ratify it.

At first blush the two pacts look mostly insubstantial. American negotiators are not interested in offering greater market access for Asian exporters, robbing IPEF of the raison d'être of a trade deal. Critics dismiss RCEP as broad but shallow because it does not cover labour rights, the environment and state-owned enterprises.

Despite those limitations, however, RCEP is already expanding China's commercial heft. Whereas the value of Chinese exports to America and the EU dropped by 15% and 5% respectively in the five months to June, compared with the same period in 2022, exports to the Association of South-East Asian Nations grew by 8% over the period. The ten-member bloc is now China's largest trading partner.

It helps that the area where RCEP has made most progress—harmonising rules of origin for goods exports—matters a lot to the complex supply chain that runs across the world's biggest manufacturing hub. The deal, in effect, creates a single market in the intermediate goods that go into final products, helping RCEP to prevent the so-called “noodle-bowl” of dozens of overlapping trade deals that exporters struggle to digest.

That makes the region “a kind of tariff-free supply web”, says Aditya Gahlaut of HSBC , a bank. The reduced complexity is more attractive to Asia's countless small businesses and encourages investment in production that takes place in RCEP countries, instead of elsewhere.

Another selling point is that RCEP may well make its members richer. That will not be thanks to tariff reductions, which are too puny to matter. A recent World Bank study projects that they will raise local real incomes by only 0.07% by 2035. Instead gains will come in the form of improvements in productivity brought about by fewer trade frictions and more liberal rules of origin. The bank reckons trade between RCEP countries could rise by a whopping 12% over the same period, compared with a no-deal scenario.

There is still time for IPEF to catch up. Some of America's Asian allies hope a Biden win at next year's presidential election will change the mood music in Washington, enabling faster progress. For now that looks optimistic. One former trade negotiator jokes that the fact that India is a member of IPEF is a signal that any future agreements will be toothless.该国政府选择退出《跨太平洋伙伴关系协定》（ IPEF更大胆的前身）和《区域全面经济伙伴关系协定》，并刻意避免真正有意义的多边贸易协定。 By casting a wide net, America has ensured that IPEF can advance only at the pace of its slowest member. ■

; Thu, 15 Jun 2023 10:10:55 GMT /content/dvb3h8qk1s8gohpjh7mvf5dm6phj2u2o https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/06/15/america-is-losing-ground-in-asian-trade Sooner or later, America’s financial system could seize up

M asterly inactivity is back in vogue at the Federal Reserve's rate-setting committee. After its meeting on June 14th it kept its benchmark rate on hold, rather than raising it, for the first time since January 2022. One or two more rate rises may lie ahead: Jerome Powell, the Fed's chairman, suggested so in his post-meeting press conference, and that is what investors expect. Gradually, though, the main debate among Fed watchers has shifted from how high the rate will go to how long it will stay there before being cut.

That is a knotty problem, made knottier by the fact that core prices in America (excluding volatile food and energy) rose by 5.3% in the year to May. It is also not the only one facing Mr Powell and his colleagues. They have spent the past year steadily shrinking the Fed's huge stock of Treasuries and mortgage-backed securities ( MBS ), the face value of which has fallen from $8.5trn to $7.7trn. Each month the Fed allows up to $60bn-worth of Treasuries, and $35bn of MBS , to mature without reinvesting the proceeds. Now it must decide when to stop.

This vast portfolio was amassed via the Fed's quantitative-easing ( QE ) programme, through which it bought bonds with newly created money. Conceived amid the global financial crisis of 2007-09, it was put into overdrive during the covid-19 pandemic. QE flooded markets with liquidity and nudged nervous investors into buying riskier assets—because the Fed was already buying the safest ones, which pushed their yields down. That kept the supply of credit and other risk capital flowing into the real economy. Critics decried all this as reckless money printing. But with inflation low and deflation more of a threat, they were easy to dismiss.

The return of high inflation makes QE ’s reversal (quantitative tightening, or QT ) desirable on several counts. Just as buying Treasuries brings long-term rates down, the disappearance of a buyer should raise them, complementing the tightening effect of the Fed's short-term rate rises. And if the Fed is not buying Treasuries, someone else must be holding on to them. That means they are not buying a riskier asset such as a stock or corporate bond, reducing the supply of capital to an overheated economy. Both effects should dampen price rises.

QT also bolsters the Fed's credibility. If it only ever conducted QE , and never reversed the process, accusations of money printing and currency debasement would be much harder to brush off. Inflation expectations could rise, self-fulfillingly and perhaps disastrously. So the Fed must prove it is willing to hoover up dollars as well as pump them out.

In that case, why stop at all? The simplest reason is that the Fed's tightening cycle is approaching its end. Eventually it will consider cutting short-term rates again, especially if economic cracks appear. To still be pushing long-term ones up at that point would be akin to a driver pressing the accelerator and the brake at the same time.

The more troubling reason is that, just like raising short-term rates, QT can inflict its own damage. Having been tried only once before, from 2017 to 2019 and at a much slower pace, its side-effects are poorly understood. That does not make them less dangerous. By sucking cash out of the system, the previous bout of QT prompted a near-failure of the money markets—the place where firms borrow to meet immediate funding needs and one of the world's most important pieces of financial plumbing. The Fed cleared the blockage with an emergency lending facility that it has since made permanent. It also had to halt QT .

This time it would be something else that breaks. The stockmarket is an obvious, if unthreatening, candidate: only a devastating crash would threaten financial stability. A broader liquidity crunch would be worse. Credit markets, already tight following several bank failures and rising defaults, are more likely to seize. America's Treasury, meanwhile, is set to soak up yet more liquidity. It must sell more than $1trn of debt over the coming three months to rebuild its cash buffers after the latest debt-ceiling drama. By increasing the risk of sudden market moves, that raises the odds of participants suddenly needing to raise cash for margin calls—and the risk that they cannot.

However small the ideal size of the Fed's balance-sheet, ever more shrinking could be dangerous. So QT must stop before it risks sparking a crisis that requires a return to QE .但当？ That is the central bank's next big dilemma. ■

; Thu, 15 Jun 2023 10:10:07 GMT /content/m04886b1ojgc3o2llhsf96nqbm3n8mfi https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/06/15/sooner-or-later-americas-financial-system-could-seize-up A new super-regulator takes aim at rampant corruption in Chinese finance

H ardly a day passes without someone in Chinese finance “falling off his horse”, or coming under a corruption investigation. State media warned on June 5th that the banking industry is infested with “moths”—mid-level managers who slowly ingest lenders' resources from the inside out. “Internal ghosts”, executives who use insider connections to pilfer billions from banks, often pose a greater danger. There are “nest cases”, where clusters of fraud spanning several banks are discovered at once, and “skewer cases”, in which the arrest of one banker leads to another, then another. After a recent spate of scandals an official newspaper dubbed smaller banks an “anti-corruption disaster zone”.

Such parlance hints at pervasive graft throughout China's vast financial system, which has assets of 400trn yuan ($56trn). Between January and May at least 60 financial institutions were hit with major investigations into personnel, according to official statements and press reports. Research by The Economist shows that, over the past five years, 78 executives at China's eight largest banks have been investigated or charged with corruption. Since 2018 authorities have also probed 385,000 shareholders of rural banks suspected of using the lenders as personal piggy banks.

The crackdown has shown no sign of ebbing as the Communist Party gains a much firmer grip over enforcement. In the biggest regulatory change in two decades, the central government announced earlier this year that it would create a super watchdog that oversees all areas of finance except the securities industry. How it applies its mega-powers is bound to remould a sector the health and stability of which matters hugely not just to China, but also to the global economy.

The new system is modelled on America's, which seeks to avoid overlapping mandates. The National Administration for Financial Regulation ( NAFR ), as the new watchdog is dubbed, has been granted status that moves it closer to the central government. That gives it stronger enforcement powers, similar to America's Securities and Exchange Commission. It has gained investor-protection responsibilities, akin to America's Financial Stability Oversight Council, and taken over financial oversight from the central bank (which, like the Federal Reserve, now focuses on macroprudential policy).

NAFR is preparing to take forward what has perhaps been the most extensive financial clean-up campaign in history. Starting in 2017, its predecessor scrambled to slow down a dangerous rise in risky financial activities. It tightened rules on shadow banking, shrinking the stock of shadow loans from the equivalent of 25.3% of total banking assets in 2017 to just 13.5% last year. It subdued sprawling financial firms and powerful people that had sought to manipulate the system. Among them were Anbang, an insurance group, and Baoshang Bank, a mid-tier lender. It crushed a 1trn yuan peer-to-peer lending industry, where people lent to one another via online platforms. The central government also upended the fintech empire of Jack Ma, China's most famous entrepreneur, after his company, Ant Group, built a mammoth lending business that received little regulatory scrutiny.

The new team will have to reckon with the costs of the clean-up, which are mounting. Many wealth-management products have gone bust, causing investors to protest. The bill for cleaning up urban banks and bailing out several large lenders has come to 10trn yuan. Rescuing Anbang alone cost $10bn. Tens of thousands of investors in peer-to-peer lending products have lost their savings. Nearly 630 small banks have been restructured.

The cutting down of Mr Ma has hurt China's reputation as a place safe for entrepreneurial experimentation. So has the recent detention of Bao Fan, one of China's most famous investment bankers. Senior regulators bristle at such criticisms and feel that, at least in Mr Ma's case, official actions were too timid for a risky business model. The new system will rectify that by giving NAFR regulatory control over financial holding companies such as Ant.

The vision for regulating the financial sector is becoming clear. Senior officials believe they have chosen the best features of the American system while rejecting the values of Wall Street, which, in their view, have seeped into China over two decades. The message to bankers is grim. Entrepreneurs will be allowed to continue to reap enormous fortunes. But the government does not want bankers to become exorbitantly wealthy. No celebrity financier, no matter how high-profile, appears immune from corruption probes.

NAFR has several pressing tasks ahead of it. First it must replace local financial regulators with its own teams and dismantle the connections between banks and local governments. The establishment of thousands of new banks since the 1990s and commands from politicians to build endlessly have helped feed a cesspool of bad assets. The small lenders that sprung up across the country often had close connections with local governments and the largest local companies, namely developers. In many cases tycoons who held shares in the banks, or controlled them outright, used them to fund their businesses. One result was a decade of high-speed economic growth. Another was rampant graft and poor allocation of funds.

So far the onslaught on corruption, the biggest threat to China's financial stability according to many, is proving highly effective, says Sam Radwan of Enhance, a consultancy. The number of arrests will probably fall. But to purge the financial system of the bad assets revealed by the campaign will be a big job—and it is an urgent one. Tight links between banks, property developers and city governments have left the industry with masses of risky loans. Developers and local-government companies owe China's banks 130trn yuan, or about 42% of total banking assets, according to Xing Zhaopeng of ANZ , a bank.

Most of those debts are deemed healthy. Li Yunze, who was recently appointed to lead NAFR , said on June 8th that the risks are controllable. In its most recent review of the banking system, the central bank said just 1.6% of total system assets are considered high-risk.

That could change if things get worse for developers and local governments. Both are finding it increasingly hard to pay back loans. A group of companies called local-government financing vehicles ( LGFV s), which often borrow from banks on behalf of cities and provinces, have spooked markets in recent weeks as many show signs of impending failure. Such risks often emerge suddenly and have the potential to contaminate banks. Dalian Wanda, one of China's top developers, has reportedly entered into talks with banks on a loan-relief plan. It has more than 90bn in outstanding loans. An LGFV in south-west China is rumoured to be paying back loans using local social-security funds.

Failure to handle this pile of debt threatens to mire the system in bad credit. Many such loans may not turn into toxic assets overnight. Instead, some will become long-term drags on bank profits. Another LGFV in southern China recently agreed with banks to restructure 15.6bn yuan in loans by lowering interest rates and pushing the maturity of the loans out by 20 years. In such situations banks have few other options than to extend.

Regulators have been experimenting with merging bad banks for years. So far 23 urban banks have been combined. But insiders say the process is cumbersome, can drag on for years and ultimately leads to the creation of larger bad banks. Another option is letting banks fail. This has been tested only a few times and risks causing runs on deposits—the opposite of the stability China's leaders are trying to achieve.

Large banks are absorbing some bad debts from smaller ones.但他们这样做的能力有限，而且不太可能收购陷入困境的银行的股权。 Some local state-owned firms have started injecting liquidity into rural lenders and taking shares in them, according to Chinese media. This type of recapitalisation is bolstering banks' balance-sheets and giving them more room to dispose of bad debts.

The only way to heal the sector is to recognise and treat soured loans. Efforts to do so have been haphazard. In 2019 regulators said they would require banks to declare the true scale of bad loans instead of using fancy accounting to hide them. But the pandemic then forced watchdogs to enforce the rules less stringently; they also told banks to roll over loans. This avoided mass corporate defaults, but also added to the hidden accumulation of bad assets. Now, with the pandemic at an end, the long-delayed recognition of more bad debts is starting, says Ben Fanger of ShoreVest Partners, an investor in distressed debt. This means a vast flow of toxic assets is coming on to the market.

国有资产管理公司将以折扣价购买部分债务。 Unlike 20 years ago, when the previous mountain of bad assets failed to lure bargain-hunters, there are now more local private investors willing to snap up non-performing loans from banks. Some corporate investors will also pick through the rubble of the property sector to search for distressed debts that allow them to take over projects on the cheap. As the economy slows and the extent of the financial rot is revealed, China's new regulators can only hope there are enough of them. ■
